div1.p: The writer reports the progress of the yellow fever work in South America, Mexico and West Africa and includes data tables.

In compliance with Dr. Rose's direction the following Yellow Fever
data is furnished for the information of the Board.

3. The last case of yellow fever in Central America as far as
we know was that of a Mr. Seaman who died of yellow fever in New Orleans
on December 7, having embarked from Puerto Barrios November 29, 1919. In
Dec 3
my judgment he contracted his disease in San Salvador the night of November
23, a sporadic case, a reminder of the epidemic which had apparently ended
October 15, 1919. Since then suspicious cases have been reported in San
Salvador, but not from very reliable sources. Protective anti-mosquito
work is being carefully followed in Salvador as well as in other Central
American Republics. No cases have been reported or found in Guatemala
since 1918.

The last case in Honduras was in September 1919.
" " " " Nicaragua " " November "
None in Costa Rica.

4. Mexico: The last case reported in Yucatan was in December
of last year (1919). A recent report secured by Dr. Gomler of the United
States Public Health Service, for us, gives the annual number of cases and
deaths by months, from 1899 to 1920 inclusive:

My recent investigations in Mexico (November and December 1919)
convinced me that the disease was pretty generally spread out along the
Southern and Western boundaries of Mexico as a whole, but definite data
are lacking. (See Journal of Lyster, Central America and Mexico, 1919)

5. Brazil: Two cases of yellow fever were discovered in Rio
de Janeiro during the year of 1919, one in May and the second in June.
None since. In the north of Brazil, the spread of the disease has been
confined to the coastal area between Bahia and Pernambuco. There was no
large number of cases at any one point when I was along this coast in
March of this year, but cases were being regularly reported every day or
so in the various large seaports in this area. The anti-yellow fever work
was well in hand, and the chances of complete elimination before the end
of this year seemed bright.

What Brazil is doing is shown rather well in the following report

6. West Africa: Whether or not yellow fever exists in West
Africa has not been convincingly settled in spite of the extensive work
done by the British Yellow Fever Commission as shown in their fourth re-
ports, 1914-1917. On pages 255-256, Section IV. of the Fourth and Final
Report, their general conclusions were as follows, what is known being
stated in condensed form:

“In the three Reports already issued by the Commission certain
conclusions are stated which, with others contained in this Report,
are here summarised for purposes of reference:-

(1) That the following fevers, other than Yellow Fever and
Malarial Fever, are not with on the West Coast of Africa, viz.:-
Typhoid Fever, Paratyphoid Fever, Pappataci Fever, and (possibly)
Undulent Fever and Seven Days' Fever, and possibly also Dengue Fever
in a sporadic form, but that there is no evidence of the occurrence
of widespread epidemics of any of these fevers in recent times.

(2) That Malarial Fever is the most widely spread of the fevers
met with in West Africa.

(3) That Yellow Fever is an endemic disease of the British
and other Dependencies on the West Coast of Africa. No sufficient
evidence has been obtained that the disease occurs in the Republic
of Liberia.

(4) The number of cases diagnosed in the British Dependencies
as Yellow Fever has not exceeded sixty in any one year during the
last six years, nor one hundred and eighty in all; but the Commis-
sion are of opinion that many more cases have occurred.

(5) That probably the continuous presence of the disease is
maintained by the existence of endemic foci and areas or otherwise,
rather than by its almost universal prevalence amongst the native
population.

(6) That the native population is not immune to Yellow Fever,
although, as a rule, when attacked, the natives suffer from a milder
type of the disease than the Europeans.

(7) That the nature of the virus of Yellow Fever remains un-
known.

(8) That there is no evidence that Yellow Fever has been brought
to West Africa during recent periods from outside Africa.

(9) That epidemics of a disease have occurred in other parts of
Africa presenting some features of a character similar to those met
with in Yellow Fever, and that in these epidemics the mortality amongst
the natives appears to have been much greater than usually now occurs
when natives of the Dependencies on the West Coast are attacked by Yel-
low Fever.

(10) That a disease of uncertain nature, known to the natives
by various names, as for example, Bayloo, Uto Enyin, or Yellow Eyes,
prevails in certain Dependencies, usually at a distance from the coast.

(11) That the knowledge of the diseases, other than Malaria,
common amongst the natives, both children and adults, inhabiting the
“bush” is very defective.

The Commission feel that it is hardly necessary to emphasize
the prime importance of a vigorous prosecution of anti-mosquito
measures against all mosquito-borne diseases.”

The above preliminary report has been rapidly collected for im-
mediate delivery to you as you requested. An article is now in preparation
by me with the following title,- Yellow Fever -- Its American Distribution
and Control in 1920. This article will show as far as possible thet progress
of the disease up to the present time.
